p.s: Sir David Attenborough tries to appeal to the emotions of the politicians and give them a bad conscience with the use of we and our to create a feeling of cohesion and the use of must to underline the urgency of the results if this climate conference.

Attenborough begins his speech with ana drastic image, the concentration of carbon in our atmosphere and its concetionconnection to global temperatures defines our relationship to the world see (ll. 3-6).
This serves the purpose to remind the politicians of the urgency of this topic, which makes the conference so important and lifechanginglife-changing.
He then talks about humanity's ancient history, with a number of carbon concentration in our atmosphere would bounce around and no predictable seasons and weather existed see (ll. 7f.).
With the numbers being suddenly stabilized humans were able to envolveevolve, Everything we've achieved in the last 10.000 years was enabled by stability... (ll. 12f.).

The global temperature has not wavered much until now see (ll. 13-14), the phrase until now expresses the urgency of this problem, because everything was fine for thousands of years until now (l. 14), it has a shocking and disillusional effect.
A feeling of cohesion is created by Attenborough because he talks about we see (l. 17) and our see (l. 14), this is shown with the quote The stability weall depend on is breaking (l. 17).
In addition he uses a lot of short and condensed sentences see (l. 17), to make it easier for the audience to understand and follow him.
Furthermore, in this way the urgency of this conference is emphasized, because these sentences have a disillusional effect.
This disillusional effect is stressed with the use of the first three different speakers see (ll. 21-23).

They say very negative, hopeless and shocking things like I'm absolutely terrified to bring a child to this world (l. 23) and You since you have control.We actually have no control (l. 22) or my world is melting (l. 21).
Every speaker expresses a different fear or fact that our strongly influenced by climate change.
The first speaker draws attention to the issue that the polar ice caps are melting and so is his word melting see (l. 21).

The second speaker appeals to the emotions of the politicians and gives the politicians about conscience because they think they have everything in control but in fact they do not see (l. 22), the speaker alludes how everybody suffers from their decisions (of the politicians).
Attenborough again underlines the urgency of this matter with the rhetorical question is this how our story is due to end? (l. 24).

He draws attention to the fact that climate change will effectaffect young people who are alive today and no longer some imagined future generation see (l. 26-28), he emphasizes this fact with the use of the alliteration to turn this tragedy into a triumph (l. 28).
He illustrates the urgency of this matter with the use of must (l. 30f.), additionally this is underlined with the anaphora we (ll. 29ff.) in the beginning of every sentences.
With the use of this repetition Attenborough tries to get this message into the minds of the politicians.
If people and politics change their behavior and the planet is at balance again (see l. 36) everybody will benefit from this change (see l. 34).
Attenborough explains the new nation a sustainable therefore no nation has completed its development see (ll. 36-38).
According to him we will learn this together, with leaving no one behind see (ll. 39f.), for the creation of an equal world or motivation should be hope and not fear see (ll. 40f.).
This team is emphasized with the last three speakers who share his hopeful attitude.

In their opinion we have to fix the problems see (l. 44), we have to do watch can see (l. 45) and even though it will be a challenge we should try to solve it in a quick way, but with the long termlong-term vision (ll. 45ff.).
Attenborough uses the different speakers to get this point across even better and to stress his point of view.
He again appeals to the emotions of the politician and givegives them a bad conscience to rethink the consequences of their actions.

He questions the behavior of the politicians with saying that the future generation will look at this conference and will only consider if the numbers start rising because of the commitment being made at this conference see (ll. 47-50).

Attenborough tries to motivate the politicians with saying that if working apart, we are force powerful enough to destabilize our planet, surely working together, we are powerful enough to sasve it (ll. 50f.), his hopefullhopeful attitude is symbolized with the word surely (l. 50).

Naming a personal aspect, In my lifetime, I've witnessed a terrible decline.And yours, you could and should witness a wonderful recovery (ll. 51-52), he again appeals to the emotional side of the politicians.
Furthermore with saying that they should witness a wonderful recovery (l. 52), he makes the politicians aware of their duty and kind of forces them into acting and rethinking their behavior.

Attenborough's last sentence again stress is the urgency and importance of the conference, the part desperate hope (l. 52) and the part is why the world is looking to you and why you are here (ll. 53f.) show this.
Moreover the part why the world is looking to you (l. 53) expressexpresses how was the result of the conference will affect the whole world and also how climate change is affecting the whole world.

To sum up, Sir David Attenborough appeals to the emotions of the politicians to underline the urgency of this matter, in addition he uses six different speakers to bring his opinion across more easily and he uses we end our to create a feeling of cohesion.
